title: TRGC1 and TRGC2
text:
TRGC1: T Cell Receptor Gamma Constant 1 TRGC2: T cell Receptor Gamma Constant 2
TRGC1 has an important paralog called TRGC2.
(A paralog is a gene that shares a common ancestry with another gene within the same organism.)



Elephant


Source: https://www.nature.com/articles/cmi201528/figures/1

title: About the site
text: To gather notes on learning bioinformatics and immunology & oncology.

title: sequencing requirement
text: It’s not recommended to sequence low plex AbSeq alone in a lane.

title: sequencing requirement
text: It’s not recommended to sequence low plex AbSeq alone in a lane.

title: sequencing requirement
text:
Dual index
Customers need to order additional index and primers. Index and primers go hand in hand?
8 lanes: Customers can order 4 i7 and do single index
The diversity of the index also follows the rule. Low diversity leads to low sequencing quality in index.
Reverse Primer 1 - 4: Name is Nextera, but the backbone is TrueSeq. So, it’s important to use TrueSeq chemistry.

title: visualization_umap_ridge
text: UMAP visualization sometimes doesn’t give the complete picture. Couple with Ridge (log10 or no log10) to draw a conclusion.

title: Extract genomic regions of interest
text:
This is an example about how to extract genomic regions of interest and put those sequences in a fasta file.
We will use the software SnapGene.
Firstly, download SnapGene. A free version is enough to cover this example.
https://www.snapgene.com/
Secondly, download your transcript of interest from NCBI. Please note that

text:
Publication
No detectable alloreactive transcriptional responses under standard sample preparation conditions during donor-multiplexed single-cell RNA sequencing of peripheral blood mononuclear cells | BMC Biology | Full Text (biomedcentral.com)

title: smk_algorithm_explain
text:
Plot on demo data

Whole data (Include Multiplet + Undetermined)

demo <- readRDS("~/OneDrive - BD/11_demo_data/v2_0/BD-Demo-WTA-AbSeq-SMK/BD-Demo-WTA-AbSeq-SMK_Seurat.rds")

load("~/Documents/github/single-cell-boot-camp/data/chapter2.RData")

cell_type <- tibble(type=demo$Cell_Type_Experimental, tag=demo$Sample_Tag)

# stack
x_order <- cell_type %>%
  group_by(type, tag) %>%
  tally() %>% 
  mutate(pct = n/sum(n)) %>% 
  filter(tag == "Undetermined") %>% 
  arrange(desc(pct)) %>% 
  .$type
x_order <- c(x_order, "Dendritic")

p1 <- cell_type %>% 
  mutate(type = factor(type, levels = x_order)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(type, fill = tag)) +
  geom_bar(position = "fill", ) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5, hjust = 1))



Filtered data (exclude Multiplet + Undetermined)

demo[["percent.mt"]] <- PercentageFeatureSet(demo, pattern = "^MT-")

demo@meta.data %>% 
  ggplot(aes(x=nCount_RNA, y=nFeature_RNA, color=percent.mt)) + 
  geom_point() + 
  scale_colour_gradient(low = "gray90", high = "black") +
  stat_smooth(method=lm) +
  scale_x_log10() + 
  scale_y_log10() + 
  theme_classic() +
  geom_vline(xintercept = 500, colour = "red") +
  geom_hline(yintercept = 300, colour = "red") +
  facet_wrap(~Sample_Name) +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5, hjust=1))





filtered <- subset(x = demo, 
                       subset = (nCount_RNA >= 500) & 
                         (nFeature_RNA >= 300) &
                         (nFeature_RNA <= 5000) &
                         (percent.mt < 25))

p2 <- tibble(type=filtered$Cell_Type_Experimental, tag=filtered$Sample_Tag) %>% 
  mutate(type = factor(type, levels = x_order)) %>% 
  ggplot(aes(type, fill = tag)) +
  geom_bar(position = "fill") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = 0.5, hjust = 1))


p1|p2





p1
